mxCell.value:
XAI tree

(Under development)

An interactive decision tree helping you decide which XAI method is most appropriate for your explainability need!

Click here to display user instructions.

object.label:
User instructions

The orange boxes contain questions with two or three possible answers provided in the connected red boxes.
Clicking on the red/blue boxes opens up new questions the user must answer. Once the final question in the path is answered, a green box is displayed showing the name of the recommended method, in addition to very brief explanation of the method, a link to software, the original paper and other resources describing the methodology.

Extra features:

[UNDO] If you need to go back one step, click on the red/blue boxes with questions/method underneath them hides everything beneath them. If you want to clear the entire three, click on "RESET DISPLAY".

[DISPLAY] If you want to explore the entire tree, click "SHOW ENTIRE TREE".

[QUESTION HELP] If you are unsure what to answer to a specific question, click on the bolded and underscored answers in the question to show one or more examples of use cases where the specific answer is appropriate.

[FEEDBACK] We are very happy to receive feedback from our users on this tool. Please do so my opening an issue on our GitHub here.


Click here to hide these user instructions.

UserObject.label: Do you want to explain the whole model or specific predictions ?

mxCell.value:
DESIGN NOTES:
1. QUESTION NODES: width = 200, max height = 100
2. ANSWER NODES: width= 120, height = 64
3. EXAMPLE NODES: width = 350, max height =  300
4. ANSWER NOTES: width = 350, no max height
4. ALIGN THE BOTTOM OF EXAMPLE AND QUESTION NODES WITH HORIZONTAL SPACING 20
5. ALGIN THE INNER VERTICAL SIDES OF ANSWERS AND EXAMPLE NODES WITH SPACING 20
Are you interested in how the features or how the training observations impact the model/prediction?
Are you interested in the effect of recording/using/observing the features, or the effect of changing the observed values of the features?

UserObject.label: Do you want to explore one feature at a time or consider joint efforts and interactions among features?

SAGE

Short method description: Uses Shapley values from game theory to decompose the expected loss of the model onto the different features.

Interpretation: The SAGE value of a feature says (roughly) how much the expected model loss is reduced by including the specific feature into the model.

Software: sage-importance (Python)

Original paper: Covert et. al (2020)

Other resources: Blog by Ian Covert

Nice to know:

  • Computing Shapley values is computationally costly.
  • Currently available software does not account for feature dependence.

Permutation feature importance

Short method description: Permutes the features the features in the training data one by one. Those giving the large decrease in model performance are most important.

Interpretation: The relative or absolute change in model performance due to each of the feature being excluded from the model.

Software: vip (vi_permute, R), scikit-learn (permutation_importance, Python) + many others

Original paper: Breiman (2001), Fisher et al (2008)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  • Also called model reliance
  • First proposed for random forest by Breiman (2001), later generalized by Fisher et al (2008)

ALEPlots

Short method description:
Prediction changes for in small intervals of a feature are computed and averaged over the other features. The ALEPlot for this feature is the cumulative curve of these values. May also be done with two (or more) features simultaneously.

Interpretation: The function value shows the prediction value as a function of one (or two) features, while averaging out the others.

Software: ALEPlot (ALEPlot, R), ALEPython (ale_plot, Python)

Original paper: Apley & Zhu (2020)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  • Unlike the visually similar partial dependence plots (PDP), ALEPlots handles dependent features

Data Banzhaf

Short method description: Uses Banzhaf values from game theory to decompose a model performance metric onto the training observations.

Interpretation: The Banzhaf value of an observation is an unnormalized measure of how the model performance metric is affected by the inclusion of the observation.

Software: Currently not available

Original paper: Wang & Jia (2022)

Other resources: 

Nice to know:

  •  Data Shapley is a related and alternative method using Shapley values instead of Banzhaf values. There are theoretical and experiment based reasons to prefer Data Banzhaf, but Data Shapley has available software.
  • (Simpler) alternatives are Cook's distance (for (generalized) linear linear models) and influence functions.

mxCell.value: Are you interested in how the training observations or how the features impact the prediction?

Are you interested in the effect of recording/using/observing the
features, or the effect of changing the observed values of the features?

UserObject.label:
Shapley values for cluster importance

Short method description: Uses Shapley values
from game theory to decompose the prediction outcome onto clusters/subsets of the training observations.

Interpretation: The Shapley values of a cluster says (roughly!) how the prediction changes due to the cluster being included in the training set.

Software: Not available

Original paper: Brandsæter & Glad (2022)

Nice to know:
  • The method requires retraining the model on subsets of the data, which may be computationally costly.
  • The method can in theory be applied to single training obsrevations instead of clusters, but this increases the computational complexity significantly.
  • A variant of the influence function approach of Koh & Liang (2017) can also be used for this.

mxCell.value:
Are you interested in the effect of recording/using/observing the
features, the effect of changing the observed feature values?
Do you want to explore one feature at a time or consider joint efforts/interactions among features?

UserObject.label:
Influence functions for perturbing training data

Short method description: Uses the influence function from robust statistics to quantify how predictions change when training observations are modified.

Interpretation: The change in loss for prediction a by caused by perturbing a training observation [Using the matrix product directly below eq. (5) in Koh & Liang (2017)]

Software: Code from Koh & Liang (2017) [Python]

Original paper: Koh & Liang (2017) [specific method described in Sec 2.2]

Other resources: Cook & Weisberg (1980) introducing influence functions in statistics. 

Section in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:
1. The method can also be used to quantify the effect of including observations in the training set.
2. Replacing the loss by the prediction function in eq (5) of Koh & Liang (2017) changes the interpretation to how the prediction is affected by the change, instead of the prediction's loss.

mxCell.value: Do you want to obey or ignore the data distribution in the explanation? **

UserObject.label:
Conditional Shapley values

Short method description: Uses Shapley values from game theory to decompose the prediction outcome onto the different features. Uses conditional expectation to measure feature contribution, and obeys the data distribution when estimating these.

Interpretation: The Shapley value of a feature says (roughly!) how of the prediction changed due to the feature being observed.

Software: shapr (R)

Original paper: Aas et al. (2020)

Other resources: Sec 5.1 of review paper by Chen et al. (2022) describing the difference between conditional and marginal Shapley values.

Nice to know:

  • Estimation of the conditional expectations measuring the feature contribution is a reserach topic on its own. For continuous unimodal data, we recommend the Gaussian or "empirical" approach, for mixed data we recommend the ctree approach

Marginal Shapley values

Short method description: Uses Shapley values
from game theory to decompose the prediction outcome onto the different
features. Uses conditional expectation to measure feature contribution,
but ignores the data distribution when estimating them.

Interpretation: The Shapley value of a feature says (roughly!) how the prediction changed due to the feature being observed.

Software: shapr (with approach="independence", R), shap (Python)

Original paper: Lundberg & Lee (2017)

Other resources: Section in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  •  While this method is typically not recommended, it is faster than obeying the data distribution. See also the example use cases.

PredDiff (first order)

Short method description: Measure the change in prediction by observing the changes when removing each of the features.

Interpretation: The (first order) PredDiff value says how the prediction changes by observing this feature, provided all other features are observed.

Software: PredDiff (Python, not recently updated)

Original paper: Robnik-Sikonja & Kononeko (2008)

Other resources: Recent clarification paper (with extensions) of Blücher et al.

Nice to know:

  •  Is significantly faster to compute than Shapley values.
  • Higher order PredDiff includes "interaction" in the sense of observing several features. Including all interaction terms makes the method equivalent to Shapley values. May therefore be seen as a light weight approximation to Shapley vaues.

mxCell.value: Are you interested in how changes in the observed value affects a continous prediction outcome, or ultimately how the changes affects a categorical decision?
Are you interested in how changes to the observed values giving the same decision or a different decision?

UserObject.label:
Anchors

Short method description: Utilizes techniquest from reinforcement learning to search for regions in the features space around the explained prediction that gives the same decision. Presents the largest/simplest regions as if-else rules, with coverage and precision.

Interpretation: Within the region of the provided if/else-rule it is guaranteed (with the specified certainty) that the decision does not change.

Software: anchor-exp (by authors, Python),  anchorsOnR (R, no longer maintained)

Original paper: Ribeiro et al. (2018)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  •  The method comes from the same authors as the LIME method.

Counterfactual explanations

Short method description: This is an umbrella term for methods explains a prediction by providing one or more examples of (small) changes in the features that would result in a different decision based on the prediction.

Interpretation: The explanation are one or more examples of (minimal) changes in the features that would result in a different decision.

Software: mcceR (specific method, under development, R/Python), CARLA-recourse (many methods, Python)

Original paper: Wachter et al. (2017)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  • Also called algoritmic recourse.
  • There exists a large number of different counterfactual methods, with their own strenght and weaknesses.

mxCell.value: Do you want to explain the prediction in terms of one feature at a time, or consider joint interactions among features?

UserObject.label:
LIME

Short method description: LIME fits a locally interpretable (typically linear) surrogate model around the instance  to be explained. The surrogate model is used to explain the local behavior of the model.

Interpretation: When a linear model is used as surrogate, the LIME coefficients can be interpreted as the change in the prediction caused by increasing the corresponding feature value by 1.

Software: lime (by authors, Python), lime (R)

Original paper: Ribeiro et al. (2016)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

  •  While most implementations use a linear surrogate model, a simple tree model may also be a good alternative.
  • When fitting the local surrogate, most implementations sample features around the instance independently which may give spurious effects.
  • If the local fit is poor (e.g. low R-squared for linear model), the interpretation may not be trustable.

ICE

Short method description: Provides plots of the prediction outcome when changing one feature at a time and keeping the others fixed. One plot per feature.

Interpretation: How the prediction changes as a function of one feature, keeping the others fixed.

Software: iml (R), scitkit-learn (Python, function: sklearn.inspection.PartialDependenceDisplay)

Original paper: Goldstein et al. (2015)

Other resources: Chapter in Molnar's IML book

Nice to know:

 While the method can be used on a single instance, multiple instances are often shown in the same plot.
The mean of the ICE plots are the well-known PDP-plots (Partial Dependence Plots)
As only one feature is altered at a time, the method ignores any dependence among features which may lead to incorrect conclusions if the feature dependence is severe..

object.label:
EXAMPLE CASES: ONE FEATURE AT A TIME

  1. You need to supply a reduced, simplified account of individual feature contributions to respond to user requests or to explore potential tensions with legal requirements.
  2. You are developing/debugging your model and want to understand the importance of adding each of the features on top of the others.
  3. You appreciate that interactions likely play a role, but want to understand how a specific feature (e.g. age) contributes to a first approximation.

EXAMPLE CASES: CHANGING THE OBSERVED VALUES

  1. You feature space is set and defined (e.g. guided by predefined criteria set in practice, guidelines or law), and you want to understand how a given changes in feature values impact model outcomes, e.g. to show that the model adheres to expectations / regulation.
  2. Your features are prone to erratic behaviour and you want to assess the stability of model outcomes wrt to these changes.

EXAMPLE CASES: TRAINING OBSERVATIONS

  1. Data collection is costly and you want to focus your resources on the data that are most valuable for specific predictions (or the performance of the whole model).  
  2. Data may come from different sources, and you want to understand how the different sources contribute.
  3. Your features are fixed/settled, but your data has changed, e.g. due to the introduction of a new software system or a new law. You want to understand this effect.

EXAMPLE CASES: FEATURES

  1. You are developing your model and want to understand how your features shape your model behavior.
  2. You want to understand which features contribute the most to the reponse in your model.

EXAMPLE CASES: OBSERVING THE FEATURES
  1. You have built a model and wish to understand how a specific feature set compares to different feature set

EXAMPLE CASES: JOINT EFFORTS

  1. You want to the full picture including, accounting for interactions between features.

EXAMPLE CASES: WHOLE MODEL

  1. When you are interested in the model performance and “typical” behavior of the model in general.
  2. You want to assess whether the model adheres to business logic / regulatory stipulations

EXAMPLE CASES: SPECIFIC PREDICTIONS

  1. When you are interested in the model performance and behavior for specific individuals/instances/observations.
  2. Your model outcome has consequences for end users (e.g. direct or indirect access to service/benefit/options/etc)

EXAMPLE CASES: FEATURES

  1. You want to advice model users on how changes in the features affect the prediction/outcome.

EXAMPLE CASES: TRAINING OBSERVATIONS
  1. Data collection is costly and you want to focus your resources on the data that are most valuable for specific predictions (or the performance of the whole model).
  2. Data may come from different sources, and you want to understand how the different sources contribute.

EXAMPLE CASES: INCLUDING THE OBSERVATIONS

  1. You are interested in the value or effect inclusion of a specific observation or set of observations (for instance from a specific data source or so) has on a prediction.

EXAMPLE CASES: CHANGING THE OBSERVED VALUES

  1. You are interested in how sensitive a specific prediction is to a certain observation of set of observations (for instance from a specific data source).

EXAMPLE CASES: OBSERVING THE FEATURES

  1. In a case where observing or recording each feature is costly, you want to understand whether the change in the prediction due to the inclusion of the different feature is worth the extra cost.
  2. You want to understand the value or contribution that every feature brings to the prediction.

EXAMPLE CASES: CHANGING THE OBSERVED FEATURE VALUES

  1. You want to understand what is the easiest way to increase/decrease the prediction or a decision based on the prediction.
  2. You are in a situation where a decision is made based on a prediction and you want to know the easiest way(s) to reach a different decision.

EXAMPLE CASES: JOINT EFFORTS

  1. You want to the full picture including, accounting for interactions between features.
  2. This should be det default unless the different effects from the features can easily be assigned to single features.

EXAMPLE CASES: ONE FEATURE AT A TIME

  1. You need to supply a reduced, simplified account of individual feature contributions to respond to user requests or explore potential tensions with legal requirements.
  2. You appreciate that interactions likely play a role, but want to
    understand how a specific feature (e.g. age) contributes to a first approximation.

EXAMPLE CASES: CATEGORICAL DECISION
  1. Your prediction is used to make a decision, and you want to understand how changes in the observed feature values affects this decision

EXAMPLE CASES: CONTINUOUS PREDICTION
  1. Your wan to understand which features can be adjusted to cause the largest changes in the prediction.

EXAMPLE CASES: OBEY DATA DISTRIBUTION

  1. Your data stems from observational studies.
  2. You generally want to obey the data distribution. Care should be taken if you stray from this option.

EXAMPLE CASES: IGNORE DATA DISTRIBUTION
  1. You want to dig into the exact mathematical formula the model uses.
  2. The data used to fit (and predict with) the model comes from a controlled experiment, where you can control all features as you like.
  3. Your data distribution is unstable because of downstream changes to collection, recording, definitions, etc.

EXAMPLE CASES: SAME DECISION

  1. You want to understand which regions around your instance that the decision based on your prediction is unchanged.

EXAMPLE CASES: DIFFERENT DECISION
  1. You want to understand how you can most easily reach a different decision (based on your prediction) by changing some of the feature values.
  2. You want to assess if your prediction is in line with "administrative practive [NORWEGIAN: forvaltningspraksis: forutberegnelighet, saklighet, legalitet]
  3. You want to provide the user with information in support of legal rights (e.g. contradiction, consent, etc)

EXAMPLE CASES: JOINT EFFORTS AMONG FEATURES
  1. You want to the full picture including, accounting for interactions between features.

EXAMPLE CASES: ONE FEATURE AT A TIME
  1. You are debugging or exploring your model and want to understand how the model works as a function of single features.
  2. You are working with data from a control study and want to know the effect of every single feature
  3. You want a simplified view and are aware that in practice, the features contribute to prediction together.
